greeting: Greetings from The On-Line Encyclopedia of Integer Sequences! http://oeis.org/

results.name: Number of sets of n positive integers that can be placed along a circle such that the set of sums of adjacent integers forms { 1, 2, ..., n^2-n+1 }.
comment: a(1)=1, a(2)=1; conjecture: for n > 2, p prime, e > 0, if n-1 is of the form p^e then a(n)>0 else a(n)=0.
a(1)=1, a(2)=1; conjecture: for n > 2, p prime, e > 0, if n-1 is of the form p^e then a(n) = A000010(n^2-n+1)/(6e), otherwise a(n)=0.
If a(n) is nonzero, a finite projective plane of order n-1 could be constructed.

The Bruck-Ryser Theorem shows that if a finite projective plane of order q exists and q is congruent to 1 or 2 (mod 4), then q must be the sum of two squares. We could get a(22)=a(23)=0 from the Theorem.
link: Eric Weisstein's World of Mathematics, Perfect Difference Set
example: For n=3, we can choose a set { 1, 2, 4 } and place them along a circle as (1,4,2)Then the sums of adjacent numbers give all numbers from 1 to 7=3*(3-1)+1: { 1=1, 2=2, 3=1+2, 4=4, 5=1+4, 6=2+4, 7=1+2+4 }. Since such set is unique, a(3) = 1.
results.author: _Naohiro Nomoto_, Jan 16 2001
ext: More terms from Rustem Aidagulov (rustem53(AT)mail.ru), Sep 06 2005 and Jan 01 2006
